data.title: allow unix sockets to be created outside the --user-data-dir folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: all
- OS Version: GNU/Linux docker containers

this is a follow up of #28126. 

The core issue at play here is understanding that containers are not persistent. So, if I run vscode inside a docker container and user configurations are to be persistent, I need to mount the `--user-data-dir` folder into an user disk like `D:\`. This is fine in mac and linux, but not in windows using docker for windows. Example: 

```sh
$ docker run -i -t -v /d/vscode/config:/root/.vscode ninrod/vscode:latest bash
```

Sadly, I cannot do this because `/d/vscode/config` is a NTFS filesystem structure which does not understand unix sockets so `vscode` crashes on startup. 

Please, allow the user to tell vscode to create these sockets that are created on `--user-data-dir` elsewhere. Example: `/var/run/vscode` or something:

```sh
.vscode $ w
 ~/.vscode at root@container using -zsh $
.vscode $ l *.sock
srwxr-xr-x 1 root root 0 Aug 24 14:16 1.14.2-main.sock
srwxr-xr-x 1 root root 0 Aug 24 14:16 1.14.2-shared.sock
.vscode $
```

thanks in advance.

data.title: Downgrade Electron to 1.7.3 with debug fix
The dialog Find don't keep the size
data.body:
Hello.
If I resize the dialog Find, it don't keep the size, after I reopen VSCODE.

- VSCode Version: 1.15.1  32-bit
- OS Version: Windows 10  64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open vscode
2. Edit > Find  (the dialog is too small)
3. resize the dialog 
4. close vscode
5. open vscode 
6. Edit > Find  (the dialog is too small)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Best regards
Danilo

data.title: Add custom width property to terminal
data.body:
Something like "terminal.integrated.lineWidth": 1.4,
It really helps when you also have fontLigatures set to true as some ligatures can look be cut off without a custom property available like this.

data.title: Add support for programmatically providing contributions
data.body:
It's already possible to contribute custom menu items etc., but they need to be explicitly defined in `package.json`, why not adding the ability to provide them programmatically?

Having this feature, [Commands](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=fabiospampinato.vscode-commands) could add support for some or all of them, enabling a very quick and powerful way to extend/customize the editor, without the need to make an extension for every little thing or even the need for learning how to do that.

Wouldn't it be great?

data.title: Add a TabBarItem object
data.body: There's already a [StatusBarItem](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#StatusBarItem) object, for adding items to the StatusBar, an analogous class for adding items to the TabBar would be awesome. Don't you think?

data.title: Allow changing the font family/settings in find/replace interface
data.body:
It would be ideal if we could change the font family and other settings used in the find/replace interface. The currently used font is pretty hard to work with when entering a complex regular expression in the input boxes (even a simple one, like "^`([^`]*)`,$", is hard to read - SS below). I'd ideally like a fixed-width font, but ultimately it seems best to have this as a setting in preferences.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1406827/29672224-3ad65d00-88b1-11e7-9314-d6f18742e77a.png)

- VSCode Version: 1.15.1 x64
- OS Version: Windows 10 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Unable to change the font family/settings that affect find/replace interface

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Objects that can trigger commands can't pass arguments to them
data.body:
There are many objects that are able to trigger commands, like [StatusBarItem](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#StatusBarItem), but not all of them (probably none of them) support a complementary `arguments` field defining the arguments that will be passed to that command's handler.

The point is that it's not even impossible to make `StatusBarItem`s pass arbitrary arguments to arbitrary commands, but it requires some [tinkering](https://github.com/fabiospampinato/vscode-commands/blob/master/src/utils.ts#L89).

Why isn't this supported by default?

data.title: Add an API for getting the shortcut bound to a command
data.body: Across the UI there are many tooltips displaying the shortcut that would execute a particular action: Unfortunately, as far as I know, this kind of information is not available via the API, so extensions cannot provide the same feature. I'd be great if you added an API for getting a command's currently bound shortcut, as well as trigger an event when that changes.

data.title: Add a `inPausedDebugMode` flag

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
There's already an `inDebugMode` flag that can be used in keystrokes' `when` clauses. It would be useful to have an `inPausedDebugMode` as well.

My use case: I've made my `workbench.action.debug.continue` shortcut be `cmd+\`, which is what Chrome uses, but that's also the same shortcut I use for splitting the editor. Basically without this flag I cannot split editors while debugging.

Having this flag would also partially fix #30810 if ever those `when` flags will be exposed via the API.

data.title: languageconfiguration: allow to modify autoClosing pairs dynamically

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Latest VSCode Insiders build as of 8/24/2017
- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 16273

The [most popular extension for LaTeX](/James-Yu/LaTeX-Workshop) is unable to implement the recommended pairings for math and display modes in LaTeX ( `\( ... \)` and `\[ ... \]` respectively (according to the official documentation, direct invocation of math mode with `$ ... $` and `$$ ... $$` is deprecated and has been for years)) as auto-closing pairs due to a [limitation directly in VSCode](/James-Yu/LaTeX-Workshop/issues/235#issuecomment-322962041).

If this isn't possible, could something please be added to at least allow the masking out of some auto-closing pairs, because as they are right now, they get in the way for me, and [I can't disable them without forking the extension](https://github.com/James-Yu/LaTeX-Workshop/issues/248) due to another limitation in VSCode.  The extension maintainer is willing to add this as well, but he said that autoclosing pairs can't be disabled with an option.

data.title: Feature Request: Manual updates on insider builds
data.body:
I understand that in an earlier issue, you resisted adding the ability to manually update when automatic updates are disabled.  However, for those of us who use the insider builds, this makes sense to do.  We're by nature the kind of people who want to read patch notes or known issues before installing the latest bleeding-edge build.  Also, the frequency of updates on the insider channel is so high that it becomes extremely annoying.

Could you reconsider adding this feature?

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---

RustyCode|sav|0.19.1

cmake-tools|vec|0.10.2

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open `~/.bash_profile`
2. Add an extra path to `$PATH` variable: `export PATH=${PATH}:/SOME_PATH`
3. Start VSCode
4. Start integrated terminal
5. Run `> echo $PATH` to see if the value added at step 2 has a duplicate.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Seeing the output of multiple terminals at the same time
data.body:
It would be really helpful is the output from multiple terminals could be redirected to appear interleaved in one place.

The terminal extension add Terminal as a drop drop in the output tab, will a message about limited future support. And not output appear here.

I haven't found anything else that looks like it could support this.

Would be really nice whilst doing micro-services development.
Any ideas?

data.title: issue with editor.formatOnPaste on json files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.13 (17A352a)
- Extensions:


Extension | Author | Version
-- | -- | --
| vscode-jest | Orta | 2.2.0 |
| vscode-docker | PeterJausovec | 0.0.16 |
| jsx | TwentyChung | 0.0.1 |
| sort-lines | Tyriar | 1.3.0 |
| yaml | adamvoss | 0.0.7 |
| vscode-caniuse | akamud | 0.5.3 |
| vscode-theme-onedark | akamud | 2.0.3 |
| theme-atom-one-dark | andischerer | 0.0.1 |
| color-info | bierner | 0.5.0 |
| vscode-javascript-snippets | codepunkt | 1.0.0 |
| gitignore | codezombiech | 0.5.0 |
| vscode-svgviewer | cssho | 1.4.2 |
| vscode-eslint | dbaeumer | 1.2.11 |
| vscode-babel-coloring | dzannotti | 0.0.4 |
| prettier-vscode | esbenp | 0.22.1 |
| flow-for-vscode | flowtype | 0.7.1 |
| theme-atom-one-dark | freebroccolo | 0.0.1 |
| Go | lukehoban | 0.6.63 |
| hex-rgba-converter | medzhidov | 1.0.4 |
| prettify-json | mohsen1 | 0.0.3 |
| atom-keybindings | ms-vscode | 3.0.1 |
| debugger-for-chrome | msjsdiag | 3.1.8 |
| vscode-json-transform | octref | 0.1.2 |
| vscode-statusbar-json-path | richie5um2 | 1.0.7 |
| vscode-icons | robertohuertasm | 7.12.0 |
| sass-indented | robinbentley | 1.4.1 |
| vscode-flow | rtorr | 276.3.0 |
| preview-vscode | searKing | 1.1.5 |
| vscode-fileutils | sleistner | 2.6.2 |
| cucumber | stevejpurves | 0.9.6 |
| json-schema-validator | tberman | 0.1.0 |
| change-case | wmaurer | 1.0.0 |
| JavaScriptSnippets | xabikos | 1.4.1 |
| commentator | zerocrunch | 1.0.3 |

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have the setting `editor.formatOnPaste: true`
2. Have a json file opened with the following content:
```json
{"key":"1 value"}
```
3. Copy the following (multi line) text:
```json
1 value other 10 values
```
4. Paste it in place of `some value`
5. Will produce that (notice the space missing between `other` & `10`):
```json
{"key": "1 value
other10 values"}
```
Expected value should be:
```json
{"key": "1 value\nother 10 values"}
```
So:
- An unnecessary trim is performed
- Carriage returns should be replaced by a `\n`

This is somehow similar to #26297 (related to HTML format and fixed by https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-html-languageservice/commit/c7e3770393646226a9f56784660438210e2ceac0).

So I guess this should be fixed somewhere into https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-json-languageservice/blob/master/src/services/jsonFormatter.ts

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (936fc3fdd9e5a47c5a626eec1ed5d81cead82d08, 2017-08-24T08:26:28.878Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2 project-manager|ale|0.19.0 vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11 gitlens|eam|4.4.1 EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4 prettier-vscode|esb|0.22.1 auto-close-tag|for|0.4.3 beautify|Hoo|1.1.1 atom-keybindings|ms-|3.0.1 vetur|oct|0.9.5 stylelint|shi|0.28.0 --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open any HTML file, **make sure you're at the very first position on the line.** 2. Type `ul>li` and then TAB. The end result is: ```
  • ``` Notice the extra `` at the end of the first line, it shouldn't be there. And definitely the cursor shouldn't be there after expansion is completed.

data.title: Some User's Emmet snippets are not shown in suggestion list in SCSS files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (936fc3fdd9e5a47c5a626eec1ed5d81cead82d08, 2017-08-24T08:26:28.878Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
project-manager|ale|0.19.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
gitlens|eam|4.4.1
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
prettier-vscode|esb|0.22.1
auto-close-tag|for|0.4.3
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
atom-keybindings|ms-|3.0.1
vetur|oct|0.9.5
stylelint|shi|0.28.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Here's my snippets.json file:
```
{
    "html": {
        "snippets": {
            "ull": "ul>li",
            "hello": "world",
            "em": "em",
            "ran": "{Use this format to get the snippet value as is}"
        }
    },
    "css": {
        "snippets": {
            "abbx": "color: black",
            "b": "border: 1px solid red",
            "hello": "world!"
        }
    }
}

```
2. In HTML file, type `hello`, and you'll see that `hello` is listed among other suggestions.

3. In SCSS file: type hello, no suggestions. Pressing TAB will produce the desired effect, which proves that the snippets are configured properly. They just not shown in SCSS among other suggestions for some reason.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Running selected code taking a long time to action
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1 x64
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise SP1

Running selected code from the editor is taking a long time (30+ seconds) using the F8 key. On occasion, the F8 key doesn't appear to do anything at all. This was not an issue in the previous version. The complexity of the selected code does not seem to be an issue, running the following took over 30 seconds to appear in the terminal window:

    Write-Host "Test"

Sometimes the selection is run immediately, as in previous versions. I ran the same selection again and it performed instantly.

Steps to Reproduce:

PowerShell terminal
1.  Select code in editor window
2. Press F8

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Run selection doesn't appear to be available without extensions.
